## We first analyse the total number of demographics for the full course
## Measure the demographics between female and male
```{r projectTemplate, include=FALSE}
library(ProjectTemplate)
load.project()
```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data=numberOfTypes(total_enrollments,age_range), aes(x=age_range, y=n)) + geom_bar(stat="identity")
```


```{r, echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data=numberOfTypes(total_enrollments,gender), aes(x=gender, y=n)) + geom_bar(stat="identity")
```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data=numberOfTypes(total_enrollments,region), aes(x=region, y=n)) + geom_bar(stat="identity")
```


```{r, echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data=numberOfTypes(total_enrollments,highest_education_level), aes(x=highest_education_level, y=n)) + geom_bar(stat="identity")
```



## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
